Pros:
Wellness Weekends are amazing 
people culture is great

Review Title: Not as human first as they claim
Pros:
Wellness weekends (shared 4 day weekends across company)
Feels like immediate team cares about you, but definitely not leadership.
As far as I'm aware recent layoffs had a nice severance (5 months). Unsure if will be that way still going forward.
Cons:
No recent salary increases. Pay is not as high as other companies. Bonus is only ever stock.
Rto mandate even though you're team is in different states and countries, so you drive in for zoom meetings. It also doesn't take into account pto or sick days, so it encourages people to come in sick. (Told you have to "plan better" if you can't make minimum...).
Half of your time will be meetings, more talking about how to do the work and not enough time to do it.
Pto amount not super generous, wellness weekends help. 
Reorgs removed required roles that business is not refilling, so more non work put on others outside of sprint commitments.

Pros: F5 used to be great, a relaxed culture where the work was the focus and management prioritized the happiness of their technical staff. The workers there are still great people, hard-working and very supportive and fun. Benefits and compensation are fair.
Cons: Upper management is entirely focused on shareholder value and they continue to change their minds on policy decisions and regularly issue new mandates without providing an opportunity for employee input. Lower level management have become enforcers who refuse to consider individual employee needs. We went from an "all voices are welcome" company to "shut up and comply" within 10 years.

Pros: Benefits, 401k medical and dental
Cons: Low stock based compensation here

Pros: Good people there enjoy the work
Cons: Management need to be improved

Review Title: Not confident in Long Term Success

* Great Team
* Can coast along if that's what you're into
* Compensation is just fine if you're in a low COL area
Cons:
* Not confident in the executive leaderships long term vision
* RTO is always rough, openly basing their takes on anecdata

Pros: It's hard to come up with many these days. Used to be such a great place to work. If they can find a way to return to being a truly human first company then I will revisit.
Cons: Forcing RTO 30 days per quarter, bonuses have been reduced for the last year and a half, no raises, hard to get promotions

Pros: great culture, financially stable, good benefits, decent pay, remote work friendly
Cons: no loyalty to employees, you are just another number and disposable as the next, very complex solutions requires more engineers to be available to assist customers, they don't celebrate wins no matter how small or large.

Pros:
Tons of opportunity - lots of smart people to work with and learn from
Great benefits, including stock plan (even for ICs)
Cons:
Getting a little weird with some DEI policies - but certainly not like typical tech companies
Not great at integrating M&As, so lots of siloing and cross-fighting

Pros: - Love some of my coworkers and have made some lifelong friends - My direct managers have been awesome and have helped me grow - Health insurance is insanely good - While I disagree with RTO, the office is nice - Work-Life Balance is pretty solid
Cons: - IT Upper management has absolutely no idea what they are doing. The blend of incompetence and sometimes borderline hostility from management has put us in a very bad spot. The recent re-org was and continues to be the worst roll out I have experienced. From what I can see, morale is at an all time low and no one knows what to do. Any time we think we are going to get an update, meetings get cancelled. Most questions get answered with anywhere between "I don't know" and "We will have to see". Productivity seems to have been effectively shut down while management decides what to do with the re-org. - Layoffs, followed by a re-org, then followed by RTO is not the way to keep talent at F5. - Compensation is all over the place. HR will work against you when it comes to being fairly compensated.

Pros: Healthy culture, bold product investments
Cons: CMO did not know her business, did not provide clarity

Review Title: My worst working experience at F5
Pros: In true sense, quickly become a manager, let other do the works and you hide in meetings and take the credit.
Cons:
Let's answer systematically
- Diversity & Inclusion ** (you have to be part of the people from same region)
- Culture & Values * (None, just copy any code from somewhere)
- Work/Life Balance 
 - for engineers ** who work is too much to do. 
 - For others *****, relax and say yes to your boss.
- Compensation and Benefits: ** Low (off course, if you are in good book of management your case is different).
- Career Opportunities : Full stop, unless you have a buddy to follow.
- Senior Management: Horrible, totally confused. Avoid them and run away.

Pros: - Good work-life balance - Decent compensation
Cons: - Poor leadership guidance. You will hear a lot of buzzwords like "Ridiculously Easy", "Human First", etc. without the actual definition of what that looks like, how to execute, and what metrics to track at individual product and overall org level - There is a lot of emphasis on bringing Amazon-style execution practice but without learning the culture. Being an ex-Amazonian I feel like they ended up just ticking the checkboxes without developing the actual day-1 culture - They acquired a bunch of companies in the last few years like Volttera, Shape Security, and Lilac but still couldn't figure out how the overall portfolio convergence will look like

Pros: Interesting technology to work on and decent time off benefits. Thats about it.
Cons: Leadership is not great. Top leadership is mishandling things in the name of efficiency, notable conflicts of interest which HR doesnt do anything about. Layoffs will continue, even for the core product organization, and moving more jobs to India.

Review Title: Great group of people but management does not lead
Pros: The people there are top notch. It is an inclusive environment, they share knowledge and help each other. Constant exposure to new ideas and technologies. Best group of people I have ever worked with.
Cons: Executive management is not leading. They are unable to articulate goals and direction of company, such as 5 year outlook, 10 year outlook, etc. New technology is up and coming they jump on it without considering what it will bring to the company other than money, so it often takes a while for them to figure out how they will incorporate it into the existing products. They give themselves bonuses and raises while the majority of the company will get promotions without pay raises. Often release security and software updates without vetting. Product versions are fragmented and span a large range making supporting various versions a nightmare.

Pros: Some pros exist in f5
Cons: The same for cons, they also exist

Review Title: Not what it used to be
Pros: Great worker bees. Very friendly environment. Smart people.
Cons: Execs are disconnected, short-sighted, and erratic. Move from 'premier focus' to another within a quarter. Very siloed. Looking for the cheapest way to make a product and are failing. Hiring junior staff and outsourcing to India.

Pros: A company with great people, innovators, leading edge products, and opportunities for growth. Good benefits and competitive pay.
Cons: A once great Seattle company caved to consultants to appease shareholders. Sadly, all that 'human first' rhetoric that was pushed during- and post- pandemic is a myth. Just corporate propaganda. Once the stock dropped to a temporary nadir in spring 2023, the leadership decided to pull the lever and RIF some 623 employees, the majority high performers. Yet, it doesn't seem that anyone at C-suite took responsibility, and all kept their jobs. However, they cored out the soul of F5.

Review Title: Too Many "Yes Men" Inexperienced in IT Services

Cons: - failing strategy - layoffs routine - reduction in benefits recently, more expected - reduction in stipends recently, more expected - forcing return to office, > 50% - too much time/focus on internal culture vs. products, services, customers

Review Title: A little less dishonesty than some companies but still full of it
Pros: Good products and strategic direction
Cons: Fairly advanced capture by the Diversity and Inclusion crowd, much time-wasting. Return to Office - for a company that prides itself on being transparent and honest, whose nominal credo starts with "First and foremost, we do the right thing" they lied their ***** off about their motivations for RTO. "We, a data-driven, numbers-based company want to impose the cataclysmic costs of commuting of up to 3 hours daily on our employees with no compensation to reap all the tax benefits which the company will retain." All the costs on us, none of the benefits. So we can have more "collaboration." Like I can collaborate better in the Seattle office with colleagues in Hyderabad than I could from home. Bullpucky. No, they are getting tax breaks for occupancy and don't care how much damage they inflict to get it. The CEO can make a case. That he failed to do so tells me there is no case to make. At least, none that would be acceptable over "because I said so." The FAQ on RTO they published reads like an essay by a student who didn't read the assignment. "How about the climate impact of all those extra trips?" "We are very concerned about climate change. (EOM)" Not concerned enough to not impose all those miles of commuting on some of the most congested roads in the U.S. So anyway, I have no trust. I hate the hypocrisy of touting corporate values they ignore. "People first" - right. Look, I'd have some respect if they were honestly exploitive instead of pretending they weren't. It's like an abuser wanting to be liked.

Pros: F5 largely maintains a "human-first" approach with its employees. This humanist philosophy has been great, but it has also begun to wear off a little as leadership has instilled a more "command and control" M.O. But you can still find good home/life balance at F5.
Cons: F5 has become more "extractive" with its work force in recent years, relying less and less on the folks in the trenches for insight. If you don't mind this, great.

Pros: F5 appreciates it's employees and shows it. Always supportive and giving opportunities to advance.
Cons: Technology Services has undergone many changes in the last couple of years. All the changes have added complexity to the environment.

Pros: No real "pros" in the past 5 years. This company is in a decline.
Cons: No Executive vision. No sales management understanding of the challenges. Weak sales management. Will most likley see another layoff in late 2023 or 2024.

Review Title: Not the company it once was
Pros: Great benefits, good corporate responsibility and donation matching, financially stable.
Cons: When I joined F5 they genuinely cared about people, doing the right thing, and supporting everyone. Now, all they care about is wringing more out from people to increase the bottom line. Deadlines are incredibly tight and have destroyed the work life balance F5 was famous for. Anyone who doesn't buy into the burnout culture they are forming is deemed expendable. Management no longer cares about employee wellness or health and their product direction is simply chasing the next release without any long term vision. Pay has been stagnant for awhile and raises are capped. Stack ranking of employees is becoming the norm where you have to mark people as low performers even if they are not. I'm not sure what happened to the company I loved, but I can no longer recommend working for them.

Pros: pay is good, benefits are great

Review Title: Back to wasting our lives commuting!!!
Pros: coherent strategy and compelling vision
Cons: layoffs and cut remote work options in half in a region with some of the worst traffic in the world. I face 240 hours a year commuting. Others face double that. All to satisfy the (few) extroverts who miss the "energy" of a crowded workplace. fully remote competitors will have a field day poaching employees. this may ne by design; f5 hasn't been hiring technical employees in the usa for years.

Review Title: Terrible senior management - Company in decline
Pros: Nice office Well known company Good work-life balance
Cons: Horrible senior level management who create chaos and disfunction every couple years with re-org after re-org (Looking at you Technology services!). People's roles get changed and forced into functions they don't have interest in or qualifications for. This is done without their consultation and senior management is open that they don't know the people they're affecting. Lower level workers have their managers changed on a whim. Critical roles overseeing functions which have no redundancy are removed leaving important gaps without any kind of replacement. Oh, and there are layoffs every other quarter. If you enjoy stability and steady direction from senior management, this is not the place for you.

Review Title: F5 is a great place to work
Pros: Human first approach, career growth and mentorship.
Cons: Return to office after being remote

Pros: I almost didn't write this for fear of retaliation. The soul of the company and the pros that we had were mostly removed in the past few years. Recent pro, wellness weekends as a few extra PTO days.
Cons: Employee engagement programs were all but shut down. People who worked across departments were all let go. Internal Promotions were almost non-existent. External hiring added management at all levels who would show up, announce a major change to boost their name and then leave. Compensation did not even try to keep up with the market. 2 years with no raises due to pandemic uncertainty, followed by a "raise" and a cut in RSUs that landed in a wash despite huge cost of living increases at the same time. RTO demands while over 3/4 of employees did not see value in returning. Distributed teams not properly managed by inflexible managers. Unreasonable hours and regular weekend work because no-one felt they could actually log off for a break. I was here for over 5 years, and there was only 1 year we did not have either a major re-org or large layoffs. Layoffs often selected employees who were not redundant forcing others to pick up the slack and learn new skills rapidly. This resulted of course in spreading resources to thin, diminishing meeting SLAs on both systems, and then the employees picking up the slack being judged for not meeting what multiple people were doing before. After years of this, the weight of 5 or more resources were being carried by individual burnt out people who had no hope for improvement or any chance at success. The company has not been releasing products internally instead acquiring other companies to bolster their product lines temporarily while showing no faith in existing engineering teams. Senior leadership would not support the suggestions that were needed to resolve issues, especially with acquired companies. D&I was a meaningful program focused on policy, benefits, and was supposed to offer a path to leadership skills and promotions. Now it is just words. The real programs no longer offer hope to employees and are used for marketing to investors and colleges.

Pros: good company, good culture, good benefits

Review Title: Mediocre pay, classic corporation, good flexibility
Pros: Company tries to be on trend with flexibility and work culture. Great office location.
Cons: The work itself is not particularly interesting and there's a lot of bureaucracy and problems preventing project efficiency needed to harness the data that the company generates.

Pros:
- Competitive tech salary 

- Wellness days and good amount of vacation means work-life balance was good for me
Cons:
- The job title I received was not the one I applied to. The responsibilities started similar, but it only took about 6 months for those to change to a different role than the one I was sold during interviews. 

- I'm not sure any managers who knew what there employees were doing. People seemed to either be doing almost nothing, or be overworked to meet deadlines. 

- Aforementioned deadlines seemed to be set before we even knew what product we were making. It's the definition of deadline driven development. 

- Technical leadership openly insulted developer's work, after remaining unhelpful through most of the projects. They were reported to upper management by multiple people for this. The reporters ended up leaving the company or team and the leadership remained the same. 

- Overall, perks are nice but not worth the stressful environment.

Review Title: stuck in the past in too many ways
Pros:
you may get a good manager or good teammates. 
the company does some D&I messaging.
you may get a chance to learn a lot in some roles.
Cons:
the cons grew to outweigh the pros by far. reviews on here suspiciously went up by 0.5 stars out of no where. notice all the positive reviews that have very little information in them. dont believe them.

extremely low pay across the board for most teams unless youre a manager or above.
going against the status quo is often ignored or frowned up. 
a lot of sr managers have very traditional views about how a company should be run in the bad way.
no true milestone rewards unless you work there for 10yrs which shows how little your time is valued.
many teams are under resourced which means people get burnt out quickly and then leave, creaing often a long unending cycle.
lots of outsourcing to exploit cheap labor.
didnt give raises to most ppl during the pandemic except to the top.
too much nepotism leading to too many unqualified leaders ruining departments.
tries to behave like a startup which doesnt work for a 25+yr old company with over 6000 employees. just means internal systems are messy and lots of instructions arent documented.
too many outdated systems and ways of doing things.

the list could go on. please do yourself a favor and listen to these words. unless youre getting a rare competitive offer to be a sr mgr or are escaping somewhere even worse to use this place as a stepping stone it isnt worth it.
